report_title: Indoor Marble Contractors in the US
executive_summary: Indoor marble contractors have endured severe uncertainty through the current period following extreme volatility in construction markets. In particular, nonresidential markets plummeted amid work-from-home and lockdown orders from federal, state and local governments. Business sentiment and corporate profit plummeted, limiting private investment. Even so, the pandemic was a boon for residential markets; fewer spending options, stimulus checks and more time at home led to greater savings, encouraging many to purchase new homes or renovate existing residences and leading to solid growth through the pandemic. Even so, climbing interest rates have slammed residential and nonresidential markets alike. Businesses and homeowners alike have remained hesitant to purchase and renovate new properties.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Homeownership Trends Bolster Revenue During The Pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic threw key construction markets into disarray, especially nonresidential markets, following business closures and lockdown orders. Many contractors lost a major revenue source during the pandemic, forcing them to refocus on more profitable segments, like residential markets. In comparison, residential markets experienced a perfect storm of positive trends, enabling this market to overachieve expectations during the pandemic. Housing starts and existing home sales climbed, aided by near-zero mortgage rates.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Low rates also support increased private spending on home improvement
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Low rates also support increased private spending on home improvement, especially on larger projects that add more resale value to homes. With more time at home, many homeowners focused on renovations too.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Climbing Interest Rates Have Limited Growth Opportunities
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite strong growth during the pandemic, climbing interest rates and skyrocketing inflation have discouraged potential buyers from spending on new construction and renovations. Consumers are more likely to forgo major investments and save. Additionally, governments have lifted stay-at-home orders, shifting consumer focus away from their homes and home improvement, causing residential markets to plummet. At the same time, lifting restrictions have benefitted nonresidential markets, creating greater demand for offices to accommodate returning employees alongside greater demand for hotels, restaurants and other travel activities.

Contractors need to account for input price volatility, including purchase and transportation costs, to maintain profit. Specifically, marble is heavy and difficult to transport, so securing long-term contracts with nearby suppliers is a good way for companies to preserve long-term profit and provide stability. Heightened local competition, especially as marble substitutes become more popular, alongside prolonged supply chain challenges have posed major threats to indoor marble contractors, especially local nonemployers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: COMPANIES WILL BENEFIT FROM EASING INTEREST RATES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Interest rates will recede through the outlook period, enabling demand from residential and nonresidential construction markets to recover. Climbing corporate profit and business sentiment will encourage businesses, especially accommodation-related establishments to invest in upgrades. Similarly, rising per capita disposable income and rebounding consumer confidence will lead to stability within household markets, particularly among single-family households. Many buyers will consider trading up from granite and other less expensive stones to marble, given higher incomes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: SUBSTITUTES WILL CONTINUE TO POSE A MAJOR THREAT
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In many cases, marble flooring, tiling and other indoor marble products are cost-prohibitive to capital-poor buyers, limiting sales to only wealthier homeowners and extremely profitable businesses. In particular, many buyers have shifted to lower-cost alternatives, like granite, white quartz and other composite materials. While these materials often fail to match the color and quality characteristics of marble, the gap is closing and will pose a major threat to indoor marble contractors through the outlook period.

industry_definition: Indoor marble contractors sell, cut and install interior marble for indoor use. Contractors also provide maintenance and repair services for marble flooring, tiles and other marble installations.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Value of residential construction

key_trends: Contractors have grappled with climbing interest rates. Residential markets have faced severe downturns, threatening growth opportunities.
Marble substitutes pose a mounting threat to interior marble contractors. Many buyers have preferred less expensive alternatives, like granite and quartz.
Contractors face few regulations. Even so, companies had to adapt business practices to COVID-19 restrictions.
Many contractors join trade groups, like the National Stone Institute. These groups provide added support to larger companies and nonemployers.
Indoor marble contractors generate the most revenue from household markets. Contractors have coped with high interest rates, leaving residential markets depressed.
Marble flooring is cost-prohibitive for many potential buyers. While marble tiling represents a less expensive alternative, many have switched to other stone alternatives.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Residential construction markets, ranging from single detached homes, mobile homes, apartment-type condominiums and attached residential buildings to standard apartment buildings. This market includes new construction, additions, renovations and repairs. Within this market, single detached homes make up the vast majority of demand, partially because of higher homeowner rates rather than rental rates, enabling owners to make more personalized design choices. Residential markets soared during the pandemic as consumers spent more time at home alongside climbing housing starts, existing home sales, private spending on home improvement and near zero interest rates.

The nonresidential construction market includes a wide range of commercial, industrial and accommodation buyers, like hotels, motels, restaurants, office buildings and industrial warehouses, factories and facilities. Like residential construction, this market includes new construction, additions, renovations and repairs. Accommodation services often represent the largest buyer with the nonresidential segment; these buyers often prioritize aesthetic and customer experience when opening a new location or remodeling. This market struggled during the pandemic as lockdown restrictions and business closures caused business sentiment to plummet; most businesses put off construction projects, limiting demand.

Utility construction and public infrastructure projects represent the smallest market for indoor marble contractors. Publicly funded municipal construction projects commonly make up the majority of this market. In general, the industry's primary markets have faltered following the pandemic despite businesses reopening as interest rates climb, limiting borrowing. Many potential projects have put off construction projects or have opted for less expensive materials.

products_and_services.product_description: Marble tiling is a cost-effective option for many buyers. Tiling services make up the vast majority of demand for indoor marble contractors. While still cost-prohibitive for many buyers, marble tiling is less expensive for contractors to install compared with solid polished marble.

Contractors also use marble in a wide range of other building finishing jobs, including countertops and miscellaneous masonry. This segment relies on design fads; for example, marble countertops frequently receive praise from home design experts, leading to periodic installation waves.

Marble flooring is cost-prohibitive for most buyers; many businesses and consumers choose marble tiling or faux marble products instead. Even so, marble tiling boasts a unique glossy appearance that enables the product to remain relevant among wealthier consumers.

tier_1_suppliers: Stone, Concrete & Clay Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Mineral & Phosphate Mining in the US
Mineral Product Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Municipal Building Construction in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Marble tiling commonly comes in glazed and unglazed finishes. Suppliers often pretreat marble tiles to prevent unwanted water absorption; marble flooring requires regular maintenance and polishing to prevent water damage. Essentially, marble tiling is significantly easier to upkeep, causing it to become heavily preferred over other marble options. It creates less waste.

basis_points.basis_description: Contractors face competition from numerous substitute materials. Wood flooring and other stone options present major challenges for marble contractors.
Competition often varies by region. Many contractors target more populous and affluent regions, leading to higher market saturation in these areas.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases consistently account for the industry's largest expense. Marble is a pricy material, especially for higher quality stone, causing companies to spend the most on source materials.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: MARBLE TILING IS A COST-EFFECTIVE OPTION FOR MANY BUYERS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Tiling services make up the vast majority of demand for indoor marble contractors. While still cost-prohibitive for many buyers, marble tiling is less expensive for contractors to install compared with solid polished marble.

Marble flooring is cost-prohibitive for most buyers; many businesses and consumers choose marble tiling or faux marble products instead. Even so, marble tiling boasts a unique glossy appearance that enables the product to remain relevant among wealthier consumers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: OTHER MARBLE BUILDING FINISHING FACES COMPETITION FROM OTHER STONES
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Contractors also use marble in a wide range of other building finishing jobs, including countertops and miscellaneous masonry. This segment relies on design fads; for example, marble countertops frequently receive praise from home design experts, leading to periodic installation waves.

FAQs.question: What are some key points about marble compared to other stones?
FAQs.answer: Marble is more difficult to work with compared with granite and other harder stones. The stone can chip easily, leading to higher installation costs and waster materials. In general, marble will face stiff competition from other stone types.
